title: How to Make a Small Tabletop Light Reflector

steps.headline: Gather together the things you'll need.
steps.description: You'll need a piece of cardboard of a decent size, reflective material and tape. There's no need to go looking for expensive reflective material – as you can see from the photos in this tutorial, a cleaned-up potato chip packet was recycled as reflective material.

steps.headline: Spread out the reflective material on the workspace.
steps.description: Face the reflective side away from you.

steps.headline: Put the cardboard on top of the reflective material.
steps.description: Center it so that what is taped isn't too bulky on one side or the other. Tape the long sides down.

steps.headline: Cut the corners of the reflective material at an angle.
steps.description: This will help it tape flatter when you tape it completely.

steps.headline: Be sure that everything is taped in the back.
Stand the reflector up.
steps.description: Obviously, it won't stand up by itself, so find something sturdy to prop it up against that is able to be hidden behind the reflector. It's now ready to be used in your tabletop photography projects.

text: Gather together the things you'll need. You'll need a piece of cardboard of a decent size, reflective material and tape. There's no need to go looking for expensive reflective material – as you can see from the photos in this tutorial, a cleaned-up potato chip packet was recycled as reflective material. Spread out the reflective material on the workspace. Face the reflective side away from you. Put the cardboard on top of the reflective material. Center it so that what is taped isn't too bulky on one side or the other. Tape the long sides down. Cut the corners of the reflective material at an angle. This will help it tape flatter when you tape it completely. Be sure that everything is taped in the back.  Stand the reflector up. Obviously, it won't stand up by itself, so find something sturdy to prop it up against that is able to be hidden behind the reflector. It's now ready to be used in your tabletop photography projects.
